title: P83-1004

sentences.text: Metagrammatical formalisms that combine context-free phrase structure rules and metarules -LRB- MPS grammars -RRB- allow concise statement of generalizations about the syntax of natural languages .
Unconstrained MPS grammars , unfortunately , are not computationally safe .
We evaluate several proposals for constraining them , basing our assessment on computational tractability and explanatory adequacy .
We show that none of them satisfies both criteria , and suggest new directions for research on alternative metagrammatical formalisms .

Entity-mp_grammar.label: MPS grammars
Entity-mp_grammar.description: A type of formalism that combines context-free phrase structure rules and metarules, allowing for concise statements about the syntax of natural languages.

Entity-unconstrained_mp_grammar.label: Unconstrained MPS grammars
Entity-unconstrained_mp_grammar.description: A type of grammar that combines context-free phrase structure rules and metarules, but lacks computational safety.

Entity-metagrammatical_formalism.label: Metagrammatical formalisms
Entity-metagrammatical_formalism.description: A type of linguistic theory that combines context-free phrase structure rules and metarules with MPS grammars, allowing for concise statement of generalizations about natural language syntax.

Entity-are_not_computationally_safe.label: are not computationally safe
Entity-are_not_computationally_safe.description: The property that unconstrained Metagrammatical Phrase Structure (MPS) grammars lack computational safety.

Entity-generalization_about_the_syntax_o.label: generalizations about the syntax of natural languages
aliases: generalizations about the syntax of natural languages
Entity-generalization_about_the_syntax_o.description: Concise statements or conclusions drawn from metagrammatical formalisms combining context-free phrase structure rules and metarules, specifically regarding the organization and structure of human language.

mentions.local_name: generalizations about the syntax of natural languages

Entity-new_direction_for_research_on_alt.label: new directions for research on alternative metagrammatical formalisms
aliases: new directions for research on alternative metagrammatical formalisms
Entity-new_direction_for_research_on_alt.description: New approaches or methods to be explored in studying non-standard grammatical frameworks that combine phrase structure rules with metarules.

mentions.local_name: new directions for research on alternative metagrammatical formalisms

Entity-mp.label: MPS
Entity-mp.description: A theoretical framework or set of rules governing the structure and formation of phrases

Entity-research_on_alternative_metagramm.label: research on alternative metagrammatical formalisms
Entity-research_on_alternative_metagramm.description: Research into exploring alternative grammatical frameworks to constrain MPS grammars.

Entity-context-free_phrase_structure_rul.label: context-free phrase structure rules
Entity-context-free_phrase_structure_rul.description: Formal guidelines for generating phrases without considering external context, used to describe the structure of sentences in a language.

Entity-computational_tractability_and_ex.label: computational tractability and explanatory adequacy
Entity-computational_tractability_and_ex.description: Evaluation criteria used to assess proposals for constraining metagrammatical formalisms.

Entity-explanatory_adequacy.label: explanatory adequacy
Entity-explanatory_adequacy.description: The criterion or standard used to assess whether a proposal for constraining MPS grammars provides an adequate explanation of their syntax.

aliases: none of them satisfies both criteria

Entity-we_(1).label: We
Entity-we_(1).description: The authors or researchers evaluating proposals for constraining MPS grammars

Entity-natural_language.label: natural languages
Entity-natural_language.description: A set of human languages that are spoken and understood by native speakers, characterized by their own grammar, vocabulary, and writing systems.

Entity-computational_tractability.label: computational tractability
Entity-computational_tractability.description: The degree to which a problem or algorithm can be efficiently solved using computer resources.

Entity-criterion.label: criteria
Entity-criterion.description: A set of rules or conditions used to evaluate or judge something

Entity-proposal.label: proposals
Entity-proposal.description: A set of ideas or suggestions

Entity-several_proposal.label: several proposals
Entity-several_proposal.description: A set of suggestions or ideas proposed as a solution to a problem

summary: Metagrammatical formalisms that combine context-free phrase structure rules and metarules -LRB- MPS grammars -RRB- allow concise statement of generalizations about the syntax of natural languages . Unconstrained MPS grammars , unfortunately , are not computationally safe . We evaluate several proposals for constraining them , basing our assessment on computational tractability and explanatory adequacy . We show that none of them satisfies both criteria , and suggest new directions for research on alternative metagrammatical formalisms .

Predicate-are.label: are
Predicate-are.description: The predicate 'are' indicates a state of being or equivalence between two entities. It connects the subject and object by stating that they share a common characteristic, property, or classification.

Predicate-evaluate.label: evaluate
Predicate-evaluate.description: To evaluate means to assess or judge the quality, value, or effectiveness of something based on specific criteria or standards. In this sense, it connects the subject (proposals) with the object (computational tractability and explanatory adequacy), indicating that the proposals are being assessed against these particular aspects.

Predicate-assess.label: assess
Predicate-assess.description: To evaluate or judge the quality, value, or significance of something based on certain criteria or standards.

Predicate-show_that_none_of_them_satisfi.label: show that none of them satisfies both criteria
Predicate-show_that_none_of_them_satisfi.description: This predicate indicates a demonstration or presentation that reveals no instance among the specified entities (them) meets both conditions or criteria. The subject (We) performs an action of showing, which connects them to the object (criteria), highlighting the absence of commonality between the two.

Predicate-suggest_new_directions_for_res.label: suggest new directions for research on alternative metagrammatical formalisms
Predicate-suggest_new_directions_for_res.description: The predicate 'suggest new directions for research on alternative metagrammatical formalisms' indicates that the subject proposes or recommends a set of potential paths or approaches (the object) to explore and investigate, with the goal of advancing knowledge or understanding in the field of metagrammatical formalisms.

Predicate-suggest.label: suggest
Predicate-suggest.description: To suggest means to propose or recommend something as a possibility or option, often implying endorsement or approval. The subject of the predicate suggests an idea, concept, or course of action that is presented for consideration by others.

Predicate-allow.label: allow
Predicate-allow.description: The predicate 'allow' indicates permission or authorization for something to occur. It implies a granting of access or freedom for an entity (subject) to engage with another entity (object), potentially within certain constraints or boundaries.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject concept is subsumed or encompassed by the object concept. In other words, it suggests a hierarchical relationship where the subject is a specific instance of the more general category represented by the object.
